author: KokoroHealth
body:
If you stop taking Ozempic after taking it regularly for 6 months, your blood glucose may rebound to around pre-treatment levels[1]. 

Ozempic is a medication used to manage blood sugar levels in people with type 2 diabetes. It encourages the pancreas to release more insulin to bring blood sugar levels back down when they rise after a meal[3]. 

Ozempic also reduces sugar production in the liver and slows down the digestion process, which helps people eat less and lose weight[3]. When people suddenly stop taking Ozempic, the amount of glucose in their blood can surge, which can be a big problem for diabetics[2][5]. 

Abruptly discontinuing Ozempic can lead to uncontrolled blood sugar levels, which can have adverse effects on your health[6]. Additionally, the weight loss that Ozempic can cause is likely to come right back once someone stops taking it[4][5]. 

If you are considering stopping Ozempic, it is important to talk to your healthcare provider first to discuss the potential risks and benefits of discontinuing the medication.

Sources
[1] What Happens After You Stop Taking Ozempic? - Everyday Health https://www.everydayhealth.com/diabetes/things-that-can-happen-after-you-stop-taking-ozempic/
[2] Ozempic Can Cause Major Weight Loss. What Happens if You Stop Taking It? https://www.nytimes.com/2023/02/03/well/live/ozempic-wegovy-weight-loss.html
[3] What Happens When You Stop Taking Ozempic? - Ro https://ro.co/weight-loss/stop-taking-ozempic/
[4] What Happens to Your Body When You Stop Taking Ozempic? - Verywell Health https://www.verywellhealth.com/what-happens-when-you-stop-ozempic-7479723
[5] What happens when you stop taking Ozempic? Doctors explain long-term effects of weight loss, diabetes drug | The Hill https://thehill.com/homenews/3891665-what-happens-when-you-stop-taking-ozempic-doctors-explain-long-term-effects-of-weight-loss-diabetes-drug/
[6] Can You Stop Taking Ozempic Suddenly and What Happens If You Do? | Felix Health https://www.felixforyou.ca/blog-posts/ozempic-can-you-stop-taking-it-suddenly-felix-health

author: Weathergod-4Life
body: Mine wasn't bad before I started taking it, my A1C was 6.9.  I was on it for about a year and it was around the same.  Then I went off it and it shot up to 8.4!  I think once you go off it that it messes with your system.  I would not recommend going on it unless you never plan on going off it.  I am working out and eating hardly any carbs and I wake up to a glucose in the mid 100s.  Before I ever went on Ozempic I would have been around 100 with the exact same diet.

author: rgold02
body: I have been on Insulin for four years now. I started Ozempic about 6 months ago. I lost about twenty pounds. Blood sugar under control. I’ve not stopped the Ozempic. So, but my blood sugar dropped to 21 this weekend. I had the nurse with Livongo call me as soon as the low number showed up. I ate a spoonful of honey immediately and had some orange juice. She stayed on the phone with me for 15 minutes and I tested again. It was 89, but too low. She advised me to eat a peanut butter and jelly sandwich. Then it went up to 159. I stayed in bed with weakness all day. I went right back to work on Monday-still weak. But, today is Tuesday and I feel so much better. When I saw “21” I freaked out and thought I was seeing it wrong. Now, I have to check before bed and in the morning-to be on the safe side. I hope this might help in some kind of way to someone. Sorry this was so long. Goldie

author: IllustriousWorld1798
body: Ozempic is a horrible drug!  It paralyzes the stomach!  Sure it lowers your A1C because it starves you!  I ended up going on long acting insulin.  I prefer that over destroying my digestive system with constant shifts in constipation and explosive diarrhea, constant Ozempic burps which are acidic, erosion of the esophagus due to excessive gas pushing acid.  A warning to all that want to try out those injectable drugs for diabetes or weight loss......DON'T!

author: Weary-Working-9761
body:
Yes!!!!!!!! I was way under control prior to going on Ozempic….A1C was 6.8, and my doctor started me on Ozempic , with the end goal to eventually get me off my daily insulin injections… 1/2 daily of Humalog and 1/daily of Lantus.
However, the severe constipation forced me to stop taking Ozempic, after about 5 weeks….But since I’ve been off Ozempic, my glucose levels have increased drastically… I’m in the 230-300 range daily and have never had numbers like this for well over 4 years. I’m now taking much more of the Humalog to control my high glucose levels.
My question is how long will this continue, and will I ever get back to the control numbers .. 100 or less.. I’ve had for years, prior to starting on Ozempic.
My doctor took me off Ozempic yesterday and started me on Jardiance , stating that I shouldn’t have the same constipation issue, I experienced, while on Ozempic.

author: wtfharlie
body:
My A1C before Ozempic was always fine. Doctor put me on Ozempic for weight loss for about 8 months and it was great. Then BCBS decided they wouldn't pay for it for anyone who doesn't have type 2 diabetes and suddenly without tapering off or anything I went from being on the 1 mg dose to nothing. It sent me into a fibromyalgia flare up for a few months, I gained the weight back and now, 9 months after stopping my A1C is 5.7 and I'm considered pre-diabetic.

I wish I had known better. Unfortunately since I suffer from chronic pain and fatigue, exercise is painful. And thanks to bad genes, a deep and wide family history of addiction, bad upbringing and an adult life of bad habits and bad decisions, dieting SEEMS impossible.

For the first few months off Ozempic I realized that my ENTIRE life I had been driven by a constant craving and was finally relieved of it on Ozempic. It was a relief to finally understand what it felt like to be satisfied by normal portion size. I never before understood how 1 cup (or less) of ANYTHING was a serving size. And once off Ozempic the gnawing craving came back with a vengeance and there is no amount of food, drink, sleep, dopamine, or anything else that will make the craving go away. And now every bite I take comes with the sense of impending doom of diabetes.
